title-group.article-title: On single damage variable models for fatigue

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion, Haifa, Israel

author-notes.corresp: Elisha Rejovitzky, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel. Email: elisha.r@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012. Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study focuses on an analytical investigation of the common characteristics of fatigue models based on a single damage variable. The general single damage variable constitutive equation is used to extract several fundamental properties. It is shown that at constant amplitude loads, damage evolution results are sufficient for predicting fatigue life under any load history. Two-level fatigue envelopes constitute an indirect measure of the damage evolution and form an alternative basis for life prediction. In addition, high-to-low and low-to-high envelopes are anti-symmetrical with respect to each other. A new integral formula for life prediction under random loads is verified with the models of Manson and Hashin, and also developed analytically for other models including Chaboche, resulting in analytical predictions. The Palmgren – Miner rule is found to yield an upper bound for fatigue life predictions under random loads, regardless of the load distribution and the specific single damage variable model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fatigue failure under varying amplitudes and especially random loads is prevalent in engineering applications. Nevertheless, the prediction of fatigue life in design still relies on phenomenological models.

The concept of damage accumulation is typically used to describe material degradation. A mathematical entity D, treated in the literature as a scalar (Hashin and Rotem, 1978), a vector (Rejovitzky and Altus, 2012), or a tensor (Lubarda and Krajcinovic, 1993), is associated with the material state at a point in time. D varies from cycle to cycle. Non-varying properties are taken as material parameters and are not a part of D. A higher number of degrees of freedom of D enables a better prediction of fatigue life. Hence, tracking damage accumulation becomes more complicated as the number of degrees of freedom increases. For this reason, single damage variable (SDV) models, for which D is a scalar (D), are still being developed: from the phenomenological point of view (Chen et al., 2006a; Cusumano and Chatterjee, 2000; Hashin and Rotem, 1978; Kujawski and Ellyin, 1988; Manson and Halford, 1986), from the continuum approach (Ayoub et al., 2011; Cheng and Plumtree, 1998; Dattoma et al., 2006; Shang and Yao, 1999), or from the micromechanical approach (Park et al., 2005). SDV models are diverse (Fatemi and Yang, 1998) and follow a wide span of manifestations of the actual damage. Devulder et al. (2010) and Van Paepegem and Degrieck (2002) defined the damage as the axial stiffness degradation. Cheng and Plumtree (1998) defined it as the reduction in ductility and Sun et al. (2007) as the relative increase in electrical resistance. Surface roughness was used as a damage measure by Crupi et al. (2000). Crack length was defined as the damage by Ibrahim and Miller (1979), Weiss (1992), Franke and Dierkes (1999), and McEvily et al. (2005).

The aim of this study is to investigate the common characteristics and limitations of all SDV models, which are important for future modeling purposes. Thus, specific SDV models are only used for demonstration and validation. Only a few studies treating this wide perspective have been found in the literature (Cusumano and Chatterjee, 2000; Hashin and Rotem, 1978; Todinov, 2001).

The first treatments of a cumulative damage problem were made by Palmgren (1924) and later by Miner (1945) under the framework of a SDV. Damage increment during every cycle was defined as the inverse of the fatigue life (N(σ)) under the uniform stress of that cycle. The damage at failure was taken as Df = 1. Thus, fatigue life N{σ(n)} was found from (1)∑m=1N{σ(n)}1N(σ(m))=Df=1. Notice that N{σ(n)} depends on the stress history up to failure. Thus, N a functional of the varying stress amplitude σ(n). The constant-amplitude stress-life (S–N) curve N(σ) constitutes a special case where σ(n) = σ = const. The Palmgren-Miner Rule (PMR) represents a commutative damage accumulation, i.e. fatigue life under different loading orders remains the same. However, experimental results (Manson and Halford, 1986; Miller and Zachariah, 1977) show significant deviations from the PMR; the values of Df vary over the wide range of 0.01 to 10 depending on the load amplitudes and loading order. Thus, the damage is non-commutative.

Two-level experiments are the simplest loading protocols used to examine the non-commutative phenomenon. On uniaxial testing, a stress σ1 is applied for n1 cycles and then σ2 for n2 cycles till failure. N(σ2) − n2 is an indirect measure of the damage at n1. Fatigue life under a high-to-low (H-L) loading order is shorter than the PMR, while the low-to-high (L-H) order is longer. Fatigue life under random loads also deviates from the PMR (Aid et al., 2011; Colin and Fatemi, 2010; Sonsino et al., 2004) as a result of the non-commutative damage accumulation. In fact, one of the main goals of SDV models is to predict this behavior.

sec.title: Basic relations
sec.p: The SDV model is based on a single scalar damage variable D, where its increment at the nth cycle (D,n) depends on D(n) and the load σ(n). The term σ(n) may have different forms. For example, under uniaxial loading and high-cycle fatigue, it may take the form, σ(n) = {σmin(n), σmax(n)}, where (·)min and (·)max are the maximum and minimum values of the cycle. Under low-cycle fatigue, a strain load may be preferred σ(n) = {ϵmin(n), ϵmax(n)}, and under multiaxial fatigue, it may contain the stress tensor and loading phase. Complex multiaxial and out-of-phase loads require a cycle-counting procedure and are not discussed herein. Notice that the SDV assumptions are still valid for a time-dependent load σ(t) in contrast to the cycle-dependent load. Thus, the full-time-dependent load history can be used for appropriate models, while keeping the validity of all the results presented here. For the same reason, the results are applicable for creep and creep–fatigue SDV models.

Additional assumptions are as follows:
The damage increment does not explicitly depend on the cycle number.
Fatigue lives under constant amplitude loads are finite.
There are no healing effects. Under these assumptions, the general SDV evolution equation is autonomous and takes the form (2)dDdn=G(σ(n),D(n))=1g(σ(n),D(n))>0, where g(·, ·) is defined for later convenience. Material parameters are included in g(·, ·), and unlike D their number is unlimited. Material variability is the main cause of scatter in fatigue life and is represented as variability in g(·, ·), which is not addressed here.

A specific form of the SDV equation (2) was suggested by Chaboche and Lesne (1988), (3)dDdn=A(σ)Dβ(σ), where σ includes the maximal and average stresses of a cycle. When selecting different β (σ) functions (Chaboche et al., 2009), equation (3) captures the behavior of other models such as Subramanyan (1976) and Hashin and Laird (1979).
The classical fatigue-life (S–N) curve N(σ) is found by integrating equation (2) at a constant load σ = const till D = Df = 1. (4)N(σ)=∫0N(σ)dn=∫01g(σ,D)dD.

sec.title: Two-level fatigue loading
sec.p: Consider a two-level loading: n1 cycles at σ1 followed by n2 cycles at σ2 till failure. From (4), (5)N1≡N(σ1)=∫01g(σ1,D)dDN2≡N(σ2)=∫01g(σ2,D)dD. N1 and N2 are used for normalization purposes. Median values of the fatigue life should be used when addressing experimental results. Two-level fatigue life is derived by integrating equation (2), (6)n1=∫0D(n1)g(σ1,D)dDn2=∫D(n1)1g(σ2,D)dD=∫01g(σ2,D)dD-∫0D(n1)g(σ2,D)dD =N2-∫0D(n1)g(σ2,D)dD. Normalizing equation (6) by Ni yields (7){n~1=N1-1∫0D(N1n~1)g(σ1,D)dDn~2=1-N2-1∫0D(N1n~1)g(σ2,D)dD, where ñi ≡ ni/Ni are the normalized number of cycles at σi. The normalized notation ·~ will be used throughout. Notice that ñ2 depends on D(N1ñ1) which in turn depends on ñ1 and σ1. Thus (8)n~2=n~2(σ2,σ1,n~1). The first basic property of SDV models follows from equation (7): two-level fatigue life n2 + n1 can be solely predicted by the constant-amplitude damage evolutions: D(n; σ1) and D(n; σ2). For example, as previously identified (Chaboche and Lesne, 1988; Todinov, 2001), SDV models which follow the PMR present self-similar damage evolutions and have the separable form: (9)dDdn=H(σ)I(D). Placing equations (9) and (5) in equation (7) yields the PMR prediction, (10)n~2=1-n~1.

Two-level envelopes are in fact indirect measures of the damage evolution. The residual life ñ2 after the first loading block depends on D(N1ñ1) and σ2 (8). Equation (7) can take the form (11)n~1eq+n~2=1, where n~1eq≡f2(σ1,σ2,n~1) is the number of cycles at σ2 that results in the same damage as n1 cycles at σ1, (12)f2(σ1,σ2,n~1)=N2-1∫0D(N1n~1)g(σ2,D)dD. Since both n~1eq and σ2 are at the same load σ2, equation (11) represents a simpler constant-amplitude load (one-level loading) for which fatigue life is known (N(σ)). Figure 1 demonstrates the equivalence properties (11) and (12): the two-level protocol is degenerated into an equivalent constant-amplitude loading at the second load. Figure 1.
Two-level loading (up) and its equivalent one-level protocol (down).

Figure 2 shows two-level fatigue envelopes predicted by equation (7) according to two well-known SDV models (Hashin and Laird, 1979; Manson and Halford, 1986) and some experimental data by Miller and Zachariah (1977). H-L and L-H uniaxial loading protocols are presented, where the x-axis is the normalized number of cycles ñL under a low-stress level σL and the y-axis is the normalized number of cycles ñH under a high-stress level σH. The two protocols manifest in different loading paths and failure envelopes. This representation of the two-level protocols can be easily generalized into a K-level loading with a K dimensional graph and K! envelopes (one for each loading combination). Notice that for both H-L and L-H orders, the PMR yields the same envelope. Thus, it is order independent, i.e. the damage accumulation is commutative. Figure 2.
Two-level fatigue envelopes. Experimental results by Miller and Zachariah (1977), and phenomenological predictions by Manson and Halford (1986) and Hashin and Laird (1979). The load follows, NH = 900; NL = 700,000.

It can be observed in Figure 2 that the two models exhibit some symmetry between the H-L and L-H predictions. This property is examined in the following, and proves to hold for all SDV models. Fatigue under a H-L order can be predicted using equation (7), (13){n~H=NH-1∫0D'g(σH,D)dD=1-NH-1∫D'1g(σH,D)dDn~L=NL-1∫D'1g(σL,D)dD=1-NL-1∫0D'g(σL,D)dD, where subscripts H and L represent the high and low stages, respectively, and D′ ≡ D(n1). Life under a L-H order is also found by switching indexes in equation (13), (14){n~L=1-NL-1∫D'1g(σL,D)dDn~H=1-NH-1∫0D'g(σH,D)dD. Comparing equation (13) with equation (14) yields (15){n~L(D'),n~H(D')}H-L={1-n~L(D'),1-n~H(D')}L-H, which means that the two envelopes are anti-symmetric: one is obtained from the other by a rotation of 180° around (0.5, 0.5); see Figure 2. This is the second basic property of all SDV models.

Considering the above symmetry and the fact that 0 ≤ ñ1 ≤ 1, it is clear that SDV two-level fatigue envelopes are limited to the range 0 ≤ ñ2 ≤ 1, i.e. the envelopes are confined by the (0, 0)−(1, 1) box. This is the third basic property of all SDV models.

Some experimental results of cumulative damage under variable loading-mode conditions (Chen et al., 2006b; Zhang and Miller, 1996) contradict SDV basic properties. Two-level experiments of torsion to axial loading and axial to torsion loading do not produce anti-symmetric two-level envelopes as predicted by the SDV assumption. Contrary to the third basic property, ñ2 reaches values up to 1.6 on axial to torsion experiments (Zhang and Miller, 1996). Hence, although multiaxial SDV models (Ayoub et al., 2011; Chaudonneret, 1993) provide good predictions for the stress-life curve, they are short of describing the damage accumulation under variable loads. Multiple damage variables (Huyen et al., 2008; Rejovitzky and Altus, 2011, 2012) are necessary in order to describe this phenomenon.

The above SDV symmetries do not determine which of the two envelopes exceeds the PMR. The condition that governs the relation between the two is found using equations (10), (13) and (14). If L-H order exceeds the PMR as seen in experiments, we have (16)NL-1∫0D'g(σL,D)dD≥NH-1∫0D'g(σH,D)dD ∀D', which is not necessarily a SDV property.

sec.title: n-Level fatigue life
sec.p: Life predictions for n-level loading can be found by generalizing equation (11). The n-level loading protocol can be degenerated into an equivalent (n − 1)-level protocol which leads to the fourth basic property: fatigue life under any multiple loading can be derived on the basis of two-level envelopes. For example, a three-level loading takes the form: (17)f2(σ2,σ3,f2(σ1,σ2,n~1)+n~2)+n~3=1. Although the above scheme is convenient for life prediction under block loading, its implementation for random loads is cumbersome and can only be performed numerically, even when the two-level envelopes are given analytically.

Equation (17) presents a basic test for the SDV assumption. The three-level fatigue life should be predictable from the two-level envelopes. Yet, a simpler test for the assumption is its symmetric behavior.

sec.title: Random fatigue life for SDV models
A prediction of random fatigue life
sec.p:
Assume that the load is stationary and ergodic, and that fatigue life is long enough with respect to the length of a representative part of the random load; i.e. D is a slowly varying function of n such that in a small increment of D, there are enough cycles to be described by the same statistical load distribution; then, the random loading is sufficiently described by its load probability density function f(σ). For illustration, a uniaxial Rayleigh distributed random load is presented in Figure 3. The distribution of the amplitudes f(σ) as sampled from the realization is presented at the left side of the figure. Figure 3.
Stationary, Rayleigh distributed stress amplitudes with stress ratio R = 0. It is seen that 50 cycles produce a sample distribution which is very close to the exact one (shown as a solid line).
In order to obtain a fatigue life prediction under random loads, we first average equation (2) over the different realizations, (18)∫0∞dDdnf(σ)dσ=∫0∞f(σ)dσg(σ(n),D(n)).

As a result of the assumption that the damage evolution is much slower than the load variations, it follows that for a small increment of D, there are enough cycles so that damage evolution can be averaged. The damage evolutions of most realizations have small variations from one another, thus we define a damage evolution D¯ which is independent of the realization. Using D¯, which depends on the load distribution, we obtain a first approximation of the fatigue life: (19)∫0∞dD¯dnf(σ)dσ=dD¯dn=∫0∞f(σ)dσg(σ(n),D¯(n)). In order to demonstrate the accuracy of the above assumption, we use Chaboche's equation (3), substitute in equation (19) and obtain the evolution of D¯. Figure 4 compares the evolutions under different realizations of a simple load with the corresponding evolution of D¯ . The load is composed of a white noise where 50% of the life is at σ1 and 50% at σ2, where β(σ1) = 0.9, β(σ2) = 0.5, and N(σ1) = N(σ2) = 500. It is seen that the variation of the damage under different realizations is relatively small even for a very low number of cycles (∼ 500). Longer fatigue lives give even smaller variations, justifying the use of D¯. It is prominent that damage evolutions under the random load significantly differ from the evolutions under constant amplitudes. Notice that fatigue life under the random load is lower than lives under the constant amplitude loads (dashed curves). This will be further discussed in `An upper bound for SDV random fatigue life predictions' section. Figure 4.
Different damage evolutions: at σ1 and σ2, under an ergodic and stationary random white noise load composed of 50% of σ1 and 50% of σ2, and a realization independent evolution D¯.

Separation of variables and integration of equation (19) yields (20)N{σ(n)}=∫01[∫0∞f(σ)dσg(σ,D¯)]-1dD¯. In order to formulate random fatigue life as a functional of the two-level envelopes, we use their slopes dn2/dn1 (Figure 2). Taking the derivative of equation (6) with respect to D¯ yields the slope at σ1 and σ2 at D¯, (21)dn2dn1(D¯,σ1,σ2)=-g(σ2,D¯)g(σ1,D¯); -∞≤dn2dn1≤0. Using equations (20) and (21) yields (22)N{σ}=-∫01g(σref,D¯)dD¯∫0∞dn2dn1(D¯,σ1,σref)f(σ1)dσ1, where σref is an arbitrary reference load. Using equation (2), the damage integration variable is replaced by ñ2. (23)N{σ}=-∫01dn~2∫0∞dn~2dn~1(n~2,σ1,σref)f(σ1)N(σ1)dσ1.

In contrast to equation (19) which requires the differential equation of the damage evolution, equation (23) predicts random fatigue life from the two-level envelopes data which is easy to measure and accessible from the literature. In addition, the definition of the damage evolution is not unique, and can be indirectly measured through different manifestations. On the other hand, the two-level fatigue life is well defined. Moreover, the two-level information includes a single reference load σref that enables the use of either H-L or L-H data on uniaxial loads. The need for partial information is in accordance with the symmetry (15). The linear PMR two-level envelopes are independent of the loads and exhibit dñ2/dñ1 = −1, thus (24)NPMR{σ}=[∫0∞f(σ)N(σ)dσ]-1. The explicit expression in equation (23) enables the derivation of some general properties of SDV models under random loads.

sec.title: Analytical fatigue life predictions for several existing SDV models
sec.p:
In the previous section, a random fatigue life formula (23) for all SDV models was developed based on f(σ) and the two-level fatigue envelopes. In this section, we obtain analytical predictions for Hashin–Chaboche type models (Chaboche and Lesne, 1988; Hashin and Laird, 1979), and for Manson and Halford's double-linear rule (Manson and Halford, 1986) based on equation (23). The predictions are for a specific load and are used to validate equation (23) by comparison with numerical simulations. Since analytical predictions of equation (23) are limited to simple loading protocols, we choose the case of a random load composed of two stress levels (σL and σH). Its stress cumulative distribution function is as follows: (25)F(σ)={0σ<σLφσL≤σ≤σH1σH<σ, where ϕ is the fraction of life at σL. Figure 5 presents a realization of equation (25) and its probability distribution function f(σ). For later convenience, we define (26)NHL≡NH/NL, as the life ratio. Figure 5.
A stationary random load with R = 0 and two stress levels: σL, σH.

sec.title: Hashin–Chaboche type models
sec.p: Many fatigue models either assume or result in the following two-level fatigue envelope: (27)n~1α(σ1,σ2)+n~2=1. where α(σ1, σ2) differs from model to model and controls the non-commutative behavior of the damage. Several examples for such models are: Subramanyan (1976), Hashin and Laird (1979), Chaboche and Lesne (1988), Kujawski and Ellyin (1988), Chaudonneret (1993), Cheng and Plumtree (1998), and Franke and Dierkes (1999).

Hashin uses (28)αHashin=ln(N2/Ne)ln(N1/Ne), where Ne is the number of cycles at the knee-point of the S–N curve. N1 = N(σ1) and N2 = N(σ2). Chaboche uses (29)αChaboche=áσ2M-σl0(1-bσ¯2)-σ¯2σu-σ2Mñ/#241;áσ1M-σl0(1-bσ¯1)-σ¯1σu-σ1Mñ, where σiM and σ¯i are the maximum stress and the average stress at the ith level, respectively. σl0, σu, and b are the fatigue limit for a fully reversed loading, the ultimate tensile stress, and a material parameter. 〈·〉 are the Macaulay brackets.
Subramanyan uses (30)αSubramanyan=σ2-σeσ1-σe, where σe is the fatigue limit.

A prediction of fatigue life under the simple load (25) is obtained by substituting equations (25) and (27) in equation (23), (31)N{σ(n)}=∫01[φN1+α(1-n~2)1-1/α1-φN2]-1dn~2, where N2 < N1 is chosen. Integration gives the fatigue life for all Hashin–Chaboche type models as: (32)[NNPMR]{σ(n)}=[1+Cα][2F1(1,A;1+A,-C)-πAC-Acsc(πA)] α≠K/(K+1), where 2F1(·, ·; ·, ·) is the ordinary hypergeometric function, K ∈ ℕ, (33)A=αα-1; C=αN1/N21-φφ. The different functions describing the fatigue life at α = K/(K + 1) are not discussed here; yet, they represent specific loads and are easily obtained by integration of equation (31). Figure 6 presents the fatigue life (32) for Hashin's model, corresponding to three NHL values. In addition, it is validated by comparing with numerical results obtained using the scheme presented in `n-Level fatigue life' section; a good analytical prediction is observed. Notice that the maximal deviation from the PMR occurs at values of ϕ which are close to one; i.e. most of the cycles are at σL and only a few are at σH. Such occurrences are typical in aviation and therefore the phenomenon may have major impact on design. Figure 6.
Analytical (32) and numerical (`n-Level fatigue life' section) fatigue life predictions for Hashin's model vs. ϕ for different NHL values; NL/Ne = 0.5. Numerical results are for a white noise loading where NPMR = 104.

sec.title: Manson and Halford’s double-linear rule
sec.p: Manson and Halford (1986) formulated a double-linear damage rule based on two stages of fatigue – crack initiation and growth. The H-L fatigue envelope follows (34)n~L={0.35β-1 0.65βn~H+1n~H<0.65β0.35β0.65β-1(n~H-1)n~H≥0.65β, where (35)β=NHL0.25. Fatigue life under the described random load (25) is found using equations (23), (34) and (35). (36)N=∫00.65β[-0.65β0.35β-1φNL+1-φNH]-1dn~L+∫0.65β1[-0.65β-1 0.35βφNL+1-φNH]-1dn~L. Integration yields: (37)[NNPMR]{σ(n)}=(φNL+1-φNH)(0.65β0.65β1-0.35βφNL+1-φNH+1-0.65β1-0.65β0.35βφNL+1-φNH).

Equation (37) is validated by comparing with numerical results obtained using the scheme presented in `n-Level fatigue life'section, as shown in Figure 7. A good correlation is observed, including a region of high deviation from the PMR. Notice that both the double-linear and Hashin's model yield very similar results. Figure 7.
Analytical (37) and numerical (`n-Level fatigue life' section) fatigue life predictions for the double-linear model vs. ϕ for different NHL values. Numerical results are for a white noise loading where NPMR = 104.

sec.title: An upper bound for SDV random fatigue life predictions
sec.p: It is observed from Figures 4, 6 and 7, that the PMR predicts higher fatigue lives. We now show that this property is valid for all SDV models and for all load distributions. This is the fifth basic property of all SDV models: (38)N{σ}≤NPMR{σ}. In order to prove equation (38), f(σ) is treated as a discrete distribution with an infinite number of load levels. Fatigue life under a load distribution composed of m levels is (39)Nm{σ}=-∫01dn~2∑i=1mdn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai, where the reference load is chosen as σm, (40)ai≡φ(σi)/N(σi)>0, and ϕ(σi) is the fraction of life at σi. Substituting the discrete form of the PMR (24) and equation (40) in the inequality (38) yields (41)Nm{σ}=-∫01dn~2∑i=1mdn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai≤1∑i=1mai. Using the axiom of induction, we prove that equation (41) holds for every m. The base case of the proof is a constant-amplitude load, i.e. a ‘random’ load composed of a single load level m = 1 (specifically, this is a limit case which is not random), (42)N1{σ}=N(σ)=NPMR{σ}, which fulfills equation (38). In the inductive step, we show that if equation (38) holds for m − 1, then it holds for m, thus it is valid for every m. Since a two-level loading with σ1 = σ2 is in fact a constant-amplitude load and dn~2dn~1(n~2,σm,σm)=-1, equation (41) takes the form: (43)∫01dn~2am-∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai≤1∑i=1mai. After some algebra, equation (43) becomes (44)∫01Tm(n~2)dn~2≥0, where using equation (21), (45)Tm(n~2)=∑i=1m-1ai+∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai∑i=1mai[∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai-am]; Tm(n~2)≤1∑i=1mai. We assume that equation (38) holds for m − 1 , i.e. (46)∫01Tm-1(n~2)dn~2≥0, where using equation (21), (47)Tm-1(n~2)=∑i=1m-1ai+∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai∑i=1m-1ai∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai; Tm-1≤1∑i=1m-1ai, and the reference load is chosen as σm. Isolating ∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai gives (48)∑i=1m-1dn~2dn~1(n~2,σi,σm)ai=∑i=1m-1aiTm-1∑i=1m-1ai-1. Placing equation (48) in equation (44) yields Tm(ñ2) as a function of Tm − 1(ñ2): (49)Tm(n~2)=ATm-1(n~2)B-Tm-1(n~2), where (50)A=∑i=1m-1aiam∑i=1mai>0; B=1∑i=1m-1ai+1am>0. We prove equation (44) by bounding it with the assumption (46) multiplied by A/B. (51)∫01Tm(n~2)dn~2≥∫01ABTm-1(n~2)dn~2≥0. Placing equation (49) in equation (51) yields (52)AB∫01Tm-12(n~2)B-Tm-1(n~2)dn~2≥0.

The nominator of equation (52) is never negative, and from equations (47) and (50), it follows that the denominator of equation (52) is always positive. Thus, equation (52) holds, and under a load composed of m levels, Miners' prediction is greater than or equal to any SDV model prediction provided that it is greater or equal for a load of m − 1 levels. Given the base case (42), equation (41) is correct for any value of m, and thus equation (38) is proved.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The SDV family of fatigue models was defined and identified (more than 20 are cited). The characteristics and limitations of this family of models were studied, and may serve as general guidelines for future predictions by more generalized models. The main SDV characteristics are as follows:
Two-level fatigue life can be solely predicted by constant amplitude damage evolutions.
H-L and L-H envelopes are anti-symmetrical.
Two-level envelopes are confined to the range 0 ≤ ñ1 ≤ 1, 0 ≤ ñ2 ≤ 1.
Under any multiple loading protocol, fatigue life can be found on the basis of two-level fatigue envelopes.
The PMR constitutes an upper bound for all SDV fatigue life predictions under random loads. A new integral formula for life prediction under random loads was developed. The formula was applied on a class of seven SDV models with a common form for the two-level envelopes, and on a bilinear damage rule. Analytical fatigue life predictions were obtained under a simple loading protocol using these models.

Some models utilize the SDV assumption to describe local material degradation while stress redistribution occurs at the macroscale (Devulder et al., 2010). In these models, there is in fact an infinite number of damage variables, one for each location in the material. While the microscale follows the SDV behavior, the whole specimen does not. An analysis which isolates the heterogeneity effect can be found in Rejovitzky and Altus (2011). Future work addressing the effects of material variability is still in demand.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful to Prof. Z Hashin of Tel Aviv University for his correspondence and also acknowledge the contribution of Prof. OV Gendelman of The Technion, Israel, regarding mathematical derivations in `An upper bound for SDV random fatigue life predictions' section.

def.p: Macaulay brackets 〈x〉 = 0 if x < 0 or 〈x〉 = x if x ≥ 0
Dirac delta function ∫-∞Xδxdx=0 if X < x and ∫-∞Xδxdx=1 if X ≥ x
